Should these methods have argument of type StringMatcher instead of Predicate? A raw predicate does not make much sense to have description?
Nits:

It seems the two and methods can be merged into one if it follows the pattern of the or method.
If any of the description is itself a combined one, e.g. a|b|c, when concatenating it again with another description, would it be helpful to put parenthesis around it, e.g. (a|b|c)&d?
@ywangd I believe this is Predicate and and or default methods signature we have to use. We can build the description from the Predicate.

These methods are not annotated with @Override. So I thought the intention was to have different methods instead of the default ones.
With that being said, Java does not have multiple dispatch. A method of public StringMatcher and(StringMatcher) does not guarantee to work as intended all the time. So its usefulness is arguable. Other options could be a new interface extending Predicate or assert the argument's type. But they are not perfect either.

The first two should be marked @Override (I think IntelliJ does weird things, with overriding default implementations...).
The 3rd (and(String,Predicate)) isn't an override, but is intentionally a Predicate so that you can apply a description to a generic predicate. It gets used in IndicesPermission for that exact purpose.
More of a question: What about empty string, all and _all? should they be handled before reaching to this class?
I don't think there's any case where those are relevant here. We don't support all in the places where this is used.
Nit: Could use a more generic parameter name instead of indices, same goes for the buildAutomataPredicate method.
Any reason this is not a Set?
I've made it a LinkedHashSet. Order has a small potential performance impact, and I don't want to break something, but there's definitely no value in duplicates.
Nit: Any concerns here about description compatibility with AutomataPredicate (comma delimited and trancating 80 strings)?

I've improved the description generation, so that it only truncates as necessary to keep the whole string under 250 characters.
I think that is to be preferred over simply attempting compatibility with the AutomataPredicate
How about adding "?" for completeness?
extra bracket?
Fixed.

Nit: Unlike the other or and and methods, this one does not have a statement of Objects.requireNonNull(other);. The relevant methods of Java Predicate calls requireNonNull anyway. So it is not really necessary to have the check here. I am happy either way, but some consistency across the methods would be good.
It delegates to the method below it, which does have the requireNotNull method. I don't think it's really needed here.
Nit: this parameter is redundant since the argument is always the field variable of allText.

I've elected to make it static instead. I think the method reads better if it simply describes the argument rather than being tied to a particular field, but if that's true then it should be a static utility method.
Nit: It is technically possible that this single item has a length greater than 250.

Yes, it is. The 250 character limit is intentionally soft. It's there to prevent us generating 10kb of toString in logs/error messages, but I don't think we actually care about 250 vs 255 or even 300 characters.

Nit: If the intention is to keep the length of the final string under 250, this only takes care of the situation when there are fewer items, but has issues when there are many items. For example, if there are 250 items and each of them takes more than 1 char, the end result will be longer than 250 chars.
Nit: seems to be unfortunate that the description constructed in the or and and methods could be longer than 250 chars after all the effort went into Builder#describe.

Nit: why not
assertNoMatch(matcher, randomFrom(nonAlpha) + randomFrom(exact1, exact2, exact3, prefix1, prefix2, suffix1, suffix2) + randomFrom(nonAlpha));
Also, why random from nonAlpha, shouldn't these tests work equally with any printable chars?
Unless they were supposed to test something that wasn't obvious to me.

Also, why random from nonAlpha, shouldn't these tests work equally with any printable chars?

Making sure that there's zero chance of overlap between the strings is hard.
For example if prefix1 is "abc" and suffix1 is "bcdef" then "a" + suffix1 + "z" will actually match because it matches prefix1.
For the purposes of this test (for multiple patterns) I felt it was easier to guarantee non-overlap by working on different alphabets.
Wow good point!

Nit: why not use the equal method of randomUnicodeOfLengthBetween that is available as part of EsTestCase?
Also, if we test unicode for description here, should it also be tested for matching?
